section.p:
This section provides details on installing the Database Service for the Development Platform.
Configure Availablility Zones
Set Quotas
Install the Database Service
Configure HAProxy

section.title: Availability Zones
section.p: To configure the Database Service in a highly available manner, it is necessary to create separate availability zones. As a best practice, HP recommends creating three availability zones. All compute hosts should be placed within one of these availability zones. If a compute host is not associated with an availability zone, the Database Service will not be able to provision a database instance to it. As a result, the Database Service may run out of capacity even though there are compute hosts with free capacity.
The following steps show how to create three availability zones and assign a compute host to the zone.

ol.li: Execute the following commands to create three availability zones named: "AZ-1", "AZ-2" and "AZ-3".nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-1 AZ-1 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-2 AZ-2 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-3 AZ-3
Validate that the availability zones were correctly created by issuing the following command.nova aggregate-list

The following commands will add a compute host to your newly created availability zones. Issue this command for every compute host that you wish to associate with an availability zone.nova aggregate-add-host <id> <hostname>
The following command can be used to list all availability zones and the compute hosts associated with them.nova availability-zone-list

section.title: Set Quotas
section.p: The admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused resources for the service to use. To check existing quota availability, log-in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

In addition to the quotas mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the admin tenant quota. The users database service quota will also be affected.

ol.li:
Source a stack RC file for the admin user and tenant.
Log in to Horizon using the admin account.
Download the OpenStack RC file.
Project > Compute > Access & Security > API Access > click Download OpenStack RC File
Source the RC file. You will need to provide the same admin password that you used to log in to Horizon. Log in to the environment, open a command line client, and execute:
source admin-openrc.sh

Create a file ~/.config/openstack/clouds.yaml and enter the configuration information for your installation in the file. The following sample configuration provides a starting point. For more detailed information, see the OpenStack client configuration documentation. The Identity URL can be found in Horizon at: Project > Compute > Access & Security > API Access. Note the URL for the Identity Service. clouds: mycloud: codn_username: hdnuser@domain.com codn_password: password horizon_url: http://<horizon-ip-address>/ cacert: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt region_name: region1 database: ephemeral_ca_cert: unset external_network: <guid of ext-net> provider_network: < guid of svc-net> ntp_server: <ip address of ntp server> keypair: default enable_ha: true flavor: m1.medium database_flavor: m1.medium messaging_flavor: m1.medium database_volume_size: 10 logstash_rabbitmq_host: < ip address of logging service> logstash_rabbitmq_password: < password for logging service> hotpools_enabled: true hotpools_max_instances: 1 hotpools_image_name: percona hotpools_flavor_names: - 'm1.medium' - 'm1.small' - 'm1.large' disable_rollback: true project_id: < project id of user to install service to> auth: auth_url: <identity url> project_name: < admin project name> username: < admin user name> password: < admin password>
List the available database versions to install: openstack hdpi list --os-cloud mycloud | grep databaseThe output should look similar to:database | wscatalog.2655 | 2.0.0.0 | available
Select the database version to install and view the details of the package openstack hdpi show wscatalog.2655 --os-cloud mycloud
Install the database service openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi database install â€“-package wscatalog.2655

section.sectiondiv:
Configure HAProxyThe following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for the Database Service.
Identify the API server IPs on the SVC network. You should have as many API servers (and IPs) as you have Availability Zones in your Helion OpenStack installation.
openstack server list | awk '/trove[0-9]*_api/{ print $4,"\t", substr($8,5) }'
Identify the Virtual IP used to load balance the Helion OpenStack services:openstack endpoint show database -c publicurl --format value
Update configuration on each of the Helion OpenStack controller nodes by connecting to the controller and doing the following:
Edit the /etc/haproxy/manual/paas.cfg file and add the following lines. The last line should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1.listen trove_api bind <virtual IP from step 2>:8779 option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 check-ssl ca-file /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
Edit the /etc/iptables/rules.v4 file and add to it:-I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Run the following command as root:sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Reload the haproxy service configurationsudo service haproxy reload
The installation is complete. Return to the Horizon dashboard (you may log out and log in with a non-Admin account if desired), and click on the Database panel under the current Project to being using Database Service.
